Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanics and Control of Brain-Machine Interface Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to derive models of human motor control and learning that improve the performance of brain-machine interfaces. Through direct measurement of brain activity, these interfaces enable people with impaired sensory-motor function to control artificial limbs and other prosthetic devices by thought alone. Inspired by evidence that human motor control is based on a discrete internal representation of motor commands and that behavioral motor recovery is similar to the acquisition of functional language, the method of approach will focus on the construction of statistical language models that allow incremental specification of motor programs. Grounded within the framework of feedback information theory and decentralized control, this approach will result in the design of feedback control systems for prosthetic devices that better reflect user intent.

If successful, this research will provide new opportunities to restore sensory-motor function, potentially improving the quality of life for people with disability due to conditions like amputation, spinal cord injury, and stroke. This research may also result in a better understanding of how the central nervous system interacts with peripheral biomechanics to control action and perception, which in turn is essential for understanding higher cognitive function and ultimately for reverse-engineering the brain. As part of a complementary educational program, the PI will facilitate interactive demonstrations for elementary school students, co-direct a week-long summer institute for high school students, and develop and assess courses preparing undergraduate and graduate students for research that integrates systems engineering and neuroscience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to derive models of human motor control and learning that improve the performance of brain-machine interface systems. Through direct measurement of brain or muscle activity, these interfaces enable people with impaired sensory-motor function to control artificial limbs and other prosthetic devices by thought alone. They can improve the quality of life for people with disability due to conditions like amputation, spinal cord injury, and stroke.

 

Advances were made in three areas.

 

First, the work produced new interfaces for upper-limb prosthetic devices. The focus was on methods of sensory substitution, restoring the ability to feel when the fingers of a prosthetic hand touch something, or to know through proprioception the configuration of each finger. For example, one method of interest was electrotactile stimulation, in which electrical current is applied over the skin to stimulate sensory nerves. The sensation that is perceived by an amputee depends on the characteristics of the electrical current waveform and on the impedance of the interface between electrodes and the skin. The work produced a model of the relationship between these parameters that made it possible to maintain a constant level of perceived sensation despite impedance changes at the electrode-skin interface.

 

Second, the work produced new interfaces for lower-limb prosthetic devices. The focus was on enabling clinical application of prosthetic legs with active knee and ankle joints. For example, one thing these prosthetic legs require is a control algorithm that decides what assistive torque should be applied about each joint. Established control algorithms work well, but have many parameters that govern their behavior and that must be turned for each individual amputee. Best practice previously would have required clinicians to choose these parameters by trial and error. The work produced a new approach that automates this process, reducing the time required from hours to minutes.

 

Third, the work produced new interfaces for EEG-based text spellers. The focus was on application of methods based on feedback information theory and on active inference to significantly enhance the rate at which human subjects can spell text with a noninvasive brain-machine interface. These methods made it possible to use flexible electrodes in a brain-machine interface, which remain in place over weeks during activities that include exercise, swimming, sleeping, and bathing, all without significant degradation of signal quality. This achievement may also expand opportunities for use of continuous EEG measurements for medical diagnostics and sleep monitoring.
